GRE High Frequency Words.list_brief_description: Barron's GRE 17th Edition High Freq Words

incorporate.word_definition: make into a whole or make part of a whole

innocuous.word_definition: not injurious to physical or mental health

coda.word_definition: the closing section of a musical composition

permeable.word_definition: allowing fluids or gases to pass or diffuse through

elegy.word_definition: a mournful poem; a lament for the dead

tenuous.word_definition: very thin in gauge or diameter

idolatry.word_definition: the worship of idols or images that are not God

obsequious.word_definition: attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery

irresolute.word_definition: uncertain how to act or proceed

intransigence.word_definition: stubborn refusal to compromise or change

distend.word_definition: cause to expand as it by internal pressure

latent.word_definition: potentially existing but not presently evident or realized

pedantic.word_definition: marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning

fervor.word_definition: feelings of great warmth and intensity

derivative.word_definition: a compound obtained from another compound

analogous.word_definition: similar or equivalent in some respects

immutable.word_definition: not subject or susceptible to change or variation

imperturbable.word_definition: marked by extreme calm and composure

contention.word_definition: the act of competing as for profit or a prize

disparate.word_definition: fundamentally different or distinct in quality or kind

iconoclastic.word_definition: characterized by attack on established beliefs

eulogy.word_definition: a formal expression of praise for someone who has died

neophyte.word_definition: any new participant in some activity

perfunctory.word_definition: hasty and without attention to detail; not thorough

eclectic.word_definition: selecting what seems best of various styles or ideas

placate.word_definition: cause to be more favorably inclined

reticent.word_definition: reluctant to draw attention to yourself

amalgamate.word_definition: to bring or combine together or with something else

malingerer.word_definition: someone shirking duty by feigning illness or incapacity

profound.word_definition: situated at or extending to great depth

levee.word_definition: an embankment built to prevent a river from overflowing

malleable.word_definition: capable of being shaped or bent

gullible.word_definition: naive and easily deceived or tricked

discrete.word_definition: constituting a separate entity or part

capricious.word_definition: determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity

dogmatic.word_definition: pertaining to a code of beliefs accepted as authoritative

homogeneous.word_definition: all of the same or similar kind or nature

repudiate.word_definition: refuse to acknowledge, ratify, or recognize as valid

sage.word_definition: a mentor in spiritual and philosophical topics

empirical.word_definition: derived from experiment and observation rather than theory

recalcitrant.word_definition: stubbornly resistant to authority or control

caustic.word_definition: capable of destroying or eating away by chemical action

stigma.word_definition: a symbol of disgrace or infamy

anarchy.word_definition: a state of lawlessness and disorder

euphemism.word_definition: an inoffensive expression substituted for an offensive one

plasticity.word_definition: the property of being physically malleable

skeptic.word_definition: someone who habitually doubts accepted beliefs

forestall.word_definition: keep from happening or arising; make impossible

invective.word_definition: abusive language used to express blame or censure

insinuate.word_definition: suggest in an indirect or covert way; give to understand

volatile.word_definition: liable to lead to sudden change or violence

apathy.word_definition: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm

commensurate.word_definition: corresponding in size or degree or extent

maverick.word_definition: someone who exhibits independence in thought and action

viable.word_definition: capable of life or normal growth and development

inert.word_definition: unable to move or resist motion

abscond.word_definition: run away, often taking something or somebody along

banal.word_definition: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse

chicanery.word_definition: the use of tricks to deceive someone

misanthrope.word_definition: someone who dislikes people in general

tacit.word_definition: implied by or inferred from actions or statements

abate.word_definition: become less in amount or intensity

preamble.word_definition: a preliminary introduction to a statute or constitution

adulterate.word_definition: make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance

dormant.word_definition: inactive but capable of becoming active

connoisseur.word_definition: an expert able to appreciate a field

inundate.word_definition: fill or cover completely, usually with water

piety.word_definition: righteousness by virtue of being pious

fallacious.word_definition: containing or based on incorrect reasoning

anomalous.word_definition: deviating from the general or common order or type

conciliatory.word_definition: making or willing to make concessions

desultory.word_definition: marked by lack of definite plan or regularity or purpose

assuage.word_definition: provide physical relief, as from pain

secrete.word_definition: generate and separate from cells or bodily fluids

penury.word_definition: a state of extreme poverty or destitution

whimsical.word_definition: determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity

officious.word_definition: intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner

qualified.word_definition: meeting the proper standards and requirements for a task

paragon.word_definition: a perfect embodiment of a concept

felicitous.word_definition: exhibiting an agreeably appropriate manner or style

deride.word_definition: treat or speak of with contempt

appropriate.word_definition: suitable for a particular person, place, or situation

assiduous.word_definition: marked by care and persistent effort

negate.word_definition: make ineffective by counterbalancing the effect of

precursor.word_definition: something indicating the approach of something or someone

aberrant.word_definition: markedly different from an accepted norm

endemic.word_definition: native to or confined to a certain region

disinterested.word_definition: unaffected by concern for one's own welfare

gouge.word_definition: an impression in a surface, as made by a blow

fawning.word_definition: attempting to win favor by flattery

verbose.word_definition: using or containing too many words

substantiate.word_definition: establish or strengthen as with new evidence or facts

indeterminate.word_definition: not fixed or known in advance

complaisant.word_definition: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others

compliant.word_definition: disposed to act in accordance with someone's wishes

zealot.word_definition: a fervent and even militant proponent of something

denigrate.word_definition: charge falsely or with malicious intent

contrite.word_definition: feeling or expressing pain or sorrow for sins or offenses

aver.word_definition: declare or affirm solemnly and formally as true

condone.word_definition: excuse, overlook, or make allowances for

artless.word_definition: simple and natural; without cunning or deceit

exculpate.word_definition: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges

mundane.word_definition: found in the ordinary course of events

dirge.word_definition: a song or hymn of mourning as a memorial to a dead person

wary.word_definition: marked by keen caution and watchful prudence

audacious.word_definition: disposed to venture or take risks

esoteric.word_definition: understandable only by an enlightened inner circle

mitigate.word_definition: lessen or to try to lessen the seriousness or extent of

embellish.word_definition: make more attractive, as by adding ornament or color

shard.word_definition: a broken piece of a brittle artifact

admonish.word_definition: scold or reprimand; take to task

flag.word_definition: a rectangular piece of cloth of distinctive design

quiescent.word_definition: being quiet or still or inactive

catalyst.word_definition: substance that initiates or accelerates a chemical reaction

mollify.word_definition: cause to be more favorably inclined

tortuous.word_definition: marked by repeated turns and bends

diffuse.word_definition: spread out; not concentrated in one place

oscillate.word_definition: move or swing from side to side regularly

default.word_definition: an option that is selected automatically

viscous.word_definition: having a relatively high resistance to flow

attenuate.word_definition: become weaker, in strength, value, or magnitude

pungent.word_definition: strong and sharp to the sense of taste

venerate.word_definition: regard with feelings of respect and reverence

refractory.word_definition: stubbornly resistant to authority or control

sporadic.word_definition: recurring in scattered or unpredictable instances

transgression.word_definition: the violation of a law or a duty or moral principle

itinerary.word_definition: an established line of travel or access

aesthetic.word_definition: characterized by an appreciation of beauty or good taste

lassitude.word_definition: a feeling of lack of interest or energy

ascetic.word_definition: someone who practices self denial as a spiritual discipline

implacable.word_definition: incapable of being appeased or pacified

digression.word_definition: a message that departs from the main subject

buttress.word_definition: a support usually of stone or brick

inchoate.word_definition: only partly in existence; imperfectly formed

spectrum.word_definition: a broad range of related objects or values or qualities

discrepancy.word_definition: a difference between conflicting facts or claims or opinions

craven.word_definition: lacking even the rudiments of courage; abjectly fearful

elicit.word_definition: call forth, as an emotion, feeling, or response

metamorphosis.word_definition: striking change in appearance or character or circumstances

impermeable.word_definition: preventing especially liquids to pass or diffuse through

stolid.word_definition: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility

impervious.word_definition: not admitting of passage or capable of being affected

boorish.word_definition: ill-mannered and coarse in behavior or appearance

impassive.word_definition: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility

efficacy.word_definition: capacity or power to produce a desired effect

harangue.word_definition: a loud bombastic declamation expressed with strong emotion

refute.word_definition: overthrow by argument, evidence, or proof

savor.word_definition: a particular taste or smell, especially an appealing one

anachronism.word_definition: something located at a time when it could not have existed

ephemeral.word_definition: anything short-lived, as an insect that lives only for a day

goad.word_definition: stab or urge on as if with a pointed stick

stint.word_definition: supply sparingly and with restricted quantities

discredit.word_definition: the state of being held in low esteem

indigence.word_definition: a state of extreme poverty or destitution

fledgling.word_definition: young bird that has just fledged or become capable of flying

insularity.word_definition: the state of being isolated or detached

quibble.word_definition: evade the truth of a point by raising irrelevant objections

reverent.word_definition: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration

emulate.word_definition: strive to equal or match, especially by imitating

discerning.word_definition: having or revealing keen insight and good judgment

ostentatious.word_definition: intended to attract notice and impress others

prohibitive.word_definition: tending to discourage, especially of prices

rarefied.word_definition: of high moral or intellectual value

disjointed.word_definition: taken apart at the points of connection

impede.word_definition: be a hindrance or obstacle to

stipulate.word_definition: make an express demand or provision in an agreement

ambiguous.word_definition: having more than one possible meaning

aggregate.word_definition: a sum total of many heterogeneous things taken together

unwarranted.word_definition: incapable of being justified or explained

coagulate.word_definition: change from a liquid to a thickened or solid state

strut.word_definition: to walk with a lofty proud gait

gregarious.word_definition: temperamentally seeking and enjoying the company of others

effrontery.word_definition: audacious behavior that you have no right to

compendium.word_definition: a publication containing a variety of works

austere.word_definition: of a stern or strict bearing or demeanor

supersede.word_definition: take the place or move into the position of

inherent.word_definition: existing as an essential constituent or characteristic

insipid.word_definition: lacking interest or significance or impact

resolution.word_definition: a decision to do something or to behave in a certain manner

meticulous.word_definition: marked by precise accordance with details

arduous.word_definition: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion

disabuse.word_definition: free somebody from an erroneous belief

pathological.word_definition: relating to the study of diseases

torpor.word_definition: a state of motor and mental inactivity

presumptuous.word_definition: going beyond what is appropriate, permitted, or courteous

extrapolation.word_definition: an inference about the future based on known facts

subpoena.word_definition: a writ issued to compel the attendance of a witness

alleviate.word_definition: provide physical relief, as from pain

deterrent.word_definition: something immaterial that interferes with action or progress

recant.word_definition: formally reject or disavow a formerly held belief

partisan.word_definition: a fervent and even militant proponent of something

document.word_definition: a representation of a person's thinking with symbolic marks

GRE High Frequency Words.list_detailed_description: Barron's GRE 17th Edition High Freq Words

100 Words Every Middle Schooler Should K.list_brief_description: American Heritage Dictionaries normally feature about 70,000 entries. From that multitude, the...

ignite.word_example: Firefighters say the blaze started when stain-soaked rags  ignited on the front porch.

replenish.word_definition: fill something that had previously been emptied
replenish.word_example: They bring in dredged sand to  replenish the beach.

dispel.word_example: For most of us,  dispelling the darkness is as simple as turning on a light.

debris.word_definition: the remains of something that has been destroyed
debris.word_example: The blast rattled their homes and sent  debris flying onto nearby properties, they said.

vigilant.word_example: Because there are so many scammers out there, banks are  vigilant about verifying that you are who you say you are.

recluse.word_example: Long before his days as the world’s most famous  recluse, Howard Hughes flew planes fast and far.

brandish.word_definition: move or swing back and forth
brandish.word_example: Hart  brandished a “Free Hugs” sign as he stood alone in front of a police barricade.

impending.word_definition: close in time; about to occur
impending.word_example: First, he gives the enemy 12 days of warning about  impending air attacks.

brackish.word_example: Brackish water can be used, but freshwater is easier and less costly.

exhilarate.word_example: “To see Yosemite Falls coming to life this morning is truly  exhilarating,” Park Superintendent Don Neubacher said in a statement.

falter.word_definition: move hesitatingly, as if about to give way
falter.word_example: “The rocket has  faltered, but it won’t crash,” he said.

cunning.word_definition: shrewdness as demonstrated by being skilled in deception
cunning.word_example: Moreover, it was no secret that Cleopatra had ruthless  cunning and superior intelligence.

momentum.word_example: Mitchell believed that a song’s  momentum should always push upward, ascending like the slope of a mountain into the unknown.

specimen.word_definition: an example regarded as typical of its class
specimen.word_example: The researchers detected it in older starfish samples, museum  specimens from as early as 1942.

translucent.word_definition: allowing light to pass through diffusely
translucent.word_example: It comes in several colors, including attractive  translucent ones.

materialize.word_example: By the time people reach their 70s, they’re beginning to look back at the plans they made and dreams they had that never  materialized.

pertinent.word_definition: having precise or logical relevance to the matter at hand
pertinent.word_example: You write about things that feel  pertinent and urgent to you, and that varies depending on what stage of life you are going through.

grueling.word_definition: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion
grueling.word_example: As of Dec. 19, 22 students will have made it through a  grueling curriculum that requires about 700 hours of computer code.

zeal.word_example: The enthusiasm has caught on among his regulars, who come often, linger and talk about pumpkins with the  zeal of converts.

imperious.word_example: It was a little scary how quickly he flipped from friendly to  imperious.

engross.word_definition: consume all of one's attention or time
engross.word_example: I don’t know how long I was reading; I was so  engrossed in the paper that I did not hear any footsteps.

furtive.word_example: What muffled whispers do they share, what  furtive games are they playing?

hasten.word_definition: speed up the progress of; facilitate
hasten.word_example: Rather than wait for that day, he set out to  hasten its arrival.

illuminate.word_definition: make free from confusion or ambiguity
illuminate.word_example: The problem is that for  illuminating answers, you need to ask the right questions.

monotonous.word_definition: sounded or spoken in a tone unvarying in pitch
monotonous.word_example: Unfortunately, their  monotonous verbiage reminds me of Charlie Brown’s teacher in the “Peanuts” TV shows.

ember.word_definition: a hot, smoldering fragment of wood left from a fire
ember.word_example: “Every hot spot is an  ember that, if not contained, can become a new fire,” Obama said.

scarcity.word_example: Water—its  scarcity, quality and the regulations affecting it—is becoming a new corporate headache.

luminous.word_example: It was briefly one of the most  luminous stars in the galaxy.

malleable.word_example: “Memory is so  malleable or volatile that each time we see something, the memory is actually influenced and re-created.”

exasperation.word_example: Like many a teenager on his school holidays, Parys is in bed, his mother explains with  exasperation.

pristine.word_definition: completely free from dirt or contamination
pristine.word_example: Back at the jail, Snow White is getting under Anna's skin a bit -- shaking her once  pristine view of the princess.

sabotage.word_definition: destroy property or hinder normal operations
sabotage.word_example: “We want at least a district that won’t  sabotage the dreams of its youths.”

repugnant.word_example: The truth is that we need only look at recent human history to find real, live, utterly  repugnant evil.

multitude.word_example: They surround you in their  multitudes - hundreds, maybe thousands of them, swooping and stinging and injecting venom into your flesh.

plenteous.word_example: "The harvest truly is  plenteous, but the labourers are few."

misgiving.word_definition: uneasiness about the fitness of an action
misgiving.word_example: Quite a few said they had come despite the  misgivings of parents who wanted them to focus on studying.

quell.word_example: The White House has tried to  quell anxieties about the danger of Ebola spreading in the United States.

unsightly.word_example: But that’s just a quibble, an  unsightly pimple on what is a greater problem.

defiance.word_example: Schools still could expel students for violating school rules or laws and could suspend students for willful  defiance of authorities in grades 4 through 12.

ominous.word_definition: threatening or foreshadowing evil or tragic developments
ominous.word_example: “Evil forces around the world want to harm Americans every day,” an  ominous voiceover states.

adversary.word_example: The students are united by shared suffering, and by a common  adversary.

obscure.word_example: The book contains little plot, an abundance of  obscure poetry and the untimely death of three protagonists.

narrate.word_example: Standing amid bags of garbage, he starts sorting, tearing open plastic bags and  narrating his finds.

circumference.word_definition: the size of something as given by the distance around it
circumference.word_example: That's almost 10 times the  circumference of the Earth, which is a surprisingly small 24,859.82 miles.

disdain.word_definition: lack of respect accompanied by a feeling of intense dislike
disdain.word_example: In the visage of Grumpy Cat, it seems, her fans found the perfect holy expression of indifferent  disdain for all things.

gusto.word_example: They each approach their tasks with  gusto that can only be admired, even if the results can’t.

scurry.word_example: Ever wonder how cockroaches  scurry around in the dark while you fumble to switch on the kitchen light?

serenity.word_definition: the absence of mental stress or anxiety
serenity.word_example: The surrounding waters and beautiful pools that surround the hotel create a real sense of calm and luxurious  serenity.

emerge.word_definition: come out into view, as from concealment
emerge.word_example: They say that program has helped them  emerge from the shadows, making possible a work permit, a Social Security number and enhanced self-respect.

bluff.word_definition: frighten someone by pretending to be stronger than one is
bluff.word_example: Sporting a pith helmet, Nixon observed that “whoever is talking the loudest is pretty sure to be  bluffing.”

terse.word_example: It’s a request to which Dipper responds, with  terse eloquence, “Weird.”

apprehensive.word_definition: in fear or dread of possible evil or harm
apprehensive.word_example: Virga still feels  apprehensive when visiting an unfamiliar zoo.

weather.word_example: You even get subjected to ridicule, and you have to  weather that storm.

aptitude.word_example: I was recently asked in an interview, what is more valued by companies –  aptitude or attitude?

habitation.word_definition: the act of dwelling in or living permanently in a place
habitation.word_example: Although the area is not fit for human  habitation, many poor people who work in the coal mines live here.

jabber.word_definition: talk in a noisy, excited, or declamatory manner
jabber.word_example: A parrot  jabbered atop its cage and a monkey squealed and battered at its bronze ring, until its owner brought bananas.

destination.word_definition: the place designated as the end, as of a race or journey
destination.word_example: Airports get stacked up with planes that can’t take off for their  destinations.

subside.word_example: The virus has a history of  subsiding, then flaring up again.

stamina.word_example: A 6-year-old might not want to walk the mile into Petra, but teenagers have enough physical and intellectual  stamina to appreciate going to these places.­

swarm.word_example: In “ Swarm” mode, the robots instead follow one another, like children chasing a soccer ball.

aplomb.word_definition: great coolness and composure under strain
aplomb.word_example: I wish I had handled it with  aplomb.

sociable.word_example: Running with others is really  sociable and great fun.

fragrance.word_definition: a distinctive odor that is pleasant
fragrance.word_example: After 30 minutes in the oven, what hits you first is the enticing, warm  fragrance that fills your kitchen.

knoll.word_example: The home, set on a quarter-acre  knoll, has views of the city, the Hollywood Reservoir and the Hollywood sign.

swagger.word_example: The Giants had arrived here with the  swagger of a team that had won two of the last four World Series titles.

eavesdrop.word_example: They  eavesdrop on the noises that other birds make while hiding food in order to steal the stash later, new research shows.

dismal.word_example: It’s been a pretty  dismal month, as far as world events go, but the news wasn’t all bad thanks to some very entertaining on-air mishaps.

jut.word_definition: extend out or project in space
jut.word_example: From its long beak  juts a fearsome tooth.

diminish.word_definition: decrease in size, extent, or range
diminish.word_example: By Friday morning, most of the heavy rain is expected to  diminish.

attentive.word_example: You make sure to be extra  attentive to your friend.

potential.word_example: What  potential global threat should policymakers pay more attention to?

versatile.word_definition: able to move freely in all directions
versatile.word_example: Eggs are among the most  versatile foods and the proteins change when you heat them, beat them or mix them with other ingredients.

banish.word_definition: send away from a place of residence, as for punishment
banish.word_example: Napoleon loses so big that he is  banished to an island.

egregious.word_definition: conspicuously and outrageously bad or reprehensible
egregious.word_example: Prosecutors questioned him about killings and other  egregious human rights abuses perpetrated by his regime.

muster.word_example: Fans chanted and hollered and enriched the arena with as much life as they could possibly  muster.

somber.word_definition: grave or even gloomy in character
somber.word_example: It was also the day before one of the most  somber of American anniversaries: Pearl Harbor was bombed 73 years ago Sunday.

foresight.word_definition: seeing ahead; knowing in advance; foreseeing
foresight.word_example: But nobody had the wherewithal or  foresight to think that day would actually happen.

barricade.word_example: The Secret Service ordered nearby streets and parking lots  barricaded for security.

uncanny.word_example: The Dark Sky App tells you the weather where you are with an  uncanny accuracy.

kindle.word_definition: call forth, as an emotion, feeling, or response
kindle.word_example: Recently in class I saw the fire of an idea flicker in a first-year student’s eyes—and so to  kindle it I cold-called him.

recuperate.word_definition: restore to good health or strength
recuperate.word_example: Sleep is the time when your body  recuperates and rebuilds from the day’s stress.

waft.word_definition: be driven or carried along, as by the air
waft.word_example: The birds were chirping, and a warm breeze  wafted through the screens.

contortion.word_definition: a tortuous and twisted shape or position
contortion.word_example: There was tumbling, human pyramids and bodies stretched into extraordinary  contortions.

headway.word_example: At times, you feel like you’re struggling to run forward, going through the motions but making no  headway, frozen in place.

jargon.word_definition: technical terminology characteristic of a particular subject
jargon.word_example: Steer clear of  jargon, me-too claims, and statements without substance.

vulnerable.word_definition: capable of being wounded or hurt
vulnerable.word_example: Second, older cells are more  vulnerable to this damage—or less able to repair themselves.

restitution.word_definition: a sum of money paid in compensation for loss or injury
restitution.word_example: While  restitution is paid to the victim, criminal fines and felony assessments are paid to a crime victims’ fund.

concoction.word_definition: any foodstuff made by combining different ingredients
concoction.word_example: There are some food combos that blend beautifully with each other to create truly tasty  concoctions.

commotion.word_example: Moments later came  commotion, followed by shouts of “Stop pushing me!”

precipice.word_example: "Every minute of every day, we were on the  precipice of failure, which is an exciting place to be," Marsh says.

jostle.word_definition: make one's way by pushing or shoving
jostle.word_example: In Jerusalem, great religions have crowded and  jostled their way down through millenniums.

tactic.word_definition: a plan for attaining a particular goal
tactic.word_example: Technology has been used as a crime-fighting  tactic, but not as a tool to determine what happens during a police action.

deft.word_definition: skillful in physical movements; especially of the hands
deft.word_example: To make it work requires a  deft hand.

outlandish.word_definition: conspicuously or grossly unconventional or unusual
outlandish.word_example: Not everything in the show is  outlandish; some events are all too realistic.

waver.word_definition: pause or hold back in uncertainty or unwillingness
waver.word_example: He is tough as nails, never  wavers, speaks the truth and stays focused.

conspicuous.word_definition: obvious to the eye or mind
conspicuous.word_example: Today, the link is more  conspicuous: highlighted in blue, it appears directly beneath the site’s login form.

meticulous.word_definition: marked by extreme care in treatment of details
meticulous.word_example: It's a six-page scene and very  meticulous, step by step.

counter.word_example: The seller can then accept,  counter or reject the offer.

persistent.word_example: It says, “together, if we face obstacles and counter the negative with a  persistent positive, we might just change the world.”

meander.word_definition: move or cause to move in a sinuous or circular course
meander.word_example: Instead of straight paths and noisy throngs, the new park will have  meandering walkways and quiet places for picnicking nestled in gently sloping "lawn valleys."

100 Words Every Middle Schooler Should K.list_detailed_description: American Heritage Dictionaries normally feature about 70,000 entries. From that multitude, the editors have chosen 100 words that are neither obscure nor outlandish that could give middle schoolers more aplomb and aptitude in their verbal encounters. If you're not sure whether that is something you need, study this list.

The Vocabulary.com Top 1000.list_brief_description: The top 1,000 vocabulary words have been carefully chosen to represent difficult but common words...

voluble.word_definition: marked by a ready flow of speech
voluble.word_example: I find him charming: shy – yet easy to talk to –  voluble and funny once he gets going.

concept.word_definition: an abstract or general idea inferred from specific instances
concept.word_example: As a psychologist, I have always found the  concept of speed dating fascinating.

partial.word_definition: being or affecting only a segment
partial.word_example: Generalizations of this sweeping order are apt to contain only  partial truth.

consider.word_example: At the moment, artemisinin-based therapies are  considered the best treatment, but cost about $10 per dose - far too much for impoverished communities.

expatiate.word_definition: add details, as to an account or idea
expatiate.word_example: He then  expatiated on his own miseries, which he detailed at full length.

machination.word_definition: a crafty and involved plot to achieve your ends
machination.word_example: He was continued a member of Congress until 1777 when his enemies succeeded in their long nursed  machinations against him.

tarry.word_example: For two days I  tarried in Paris, settling my little property.

concern.word_definition: something that interests you because it is important
concern.word_example: The scandal broke out in October after former chief executive Michael Woodford claimed he was fired for raising  concerns about the company's accounting practices.

livelihood.word_definition: the financial means whereby one lives
livelihood.word_example: With businesses shut, fields untended and fishing abandoned many have lost their  livelihoods as well as their homes, our correspondent says.

bullion.word_definition: gold or silver in bars or ingots

bequeath.word_definition: leave or give by will after one's death

ornate.word_definition: marked by complexity and richness of detail

rampart.word_definition: an embankment built around a space for defensive purposes

tenable.word_definition: based on sound reasoning or evidence

inspire.word_definition: serve as the inciting cause of

wanton.word_definition: unprovoked or without motive or justification

insensate.word_definition: devoid of feeling and consciousness and animation

aria.word_definition: an elaborate song for solo voice

expostulation.word_definition: the act of expressing earnest opposition or protest

rankle.word_definition: gnaw into; make resentful or angry

imposture.word_example: He got somebody to prosecute him for false pretences and  imposture, on the ground that Madame was a man.

tenacious.word_example: She was a  tenacious woman, one who would even hold fast a thing which she no longer valued, simply because it belonged to her.

assay.word_example: He decided to  assay one last project before giving up.

moribund.word_definition: not growing or changing; without force or vitality

candid.word_definition: openly straightforward and direct without secretiveness

refectory.word_definition: a communal dining-hall, usually in a monastery

dapper.word_definition: marked by up-to-dateness in dress and manners

pious.word_definition: having or showing or expressing reverence for a deity

harry.word_example: There’s something uplifting about hearing a string instrument when I’m feeling ragged or  harried.

enrapture.word_example: I was delighted,  enraptured, beside myself--the world had disappeared in an instant.

veritable.word_definition: being truly so called; real or genuine

advocate.word_definition: a person who pleads for a person, cause, or idea

dotage.word_definition: mental infirmity as a consequence of old age

malice.word_definition: feeling a need to see others suffer

spectral.word_definition: resembling or characteristic of a phantom

conduct.word_definition: direct the course of; manage or control

institute.word_definition: set up or lay the groundwork for

forebear.word_definition: a person from whom you are descended

apparent.word_definition: clearly revealed to the mind or the senses or judgment

intend.word_definition: have in mind as a purpose

parable.word_example: In most instances, I have closed my visits by reading some interesting story or  parable.

sluice.word_definition: pour as if from a conduit that carries a rapid flow of water

predecessor.word_definition: one who precedes you in time

visage.word_example: An honest, quiet laugh often mantled his pale earnest  visage.

nexus.word_example: Numerous innovators are also worrying away at this  nexus of problems.

assent.word_example: His two companions readily  assented, and the promise was mutually given and received.

rapt.word_example: She was watching the development of the investigation with  rapt, eager attention.

revelry.word_example: But all this  revelry — dancing, drinks, exuberant youth — can be hard to manage.

contempt.word_definition: lack of respect accompanied by a feeling of intense dislike

court.word_definition: an assembly to conduct judicial business

disconsolate.word_definition: sad beyond comforting; incapable of being consoled

cardinal.word_definition: one of a group of prominent bishops in the Sacred College

ruse.word_example: Overseas criminals use elaborate  ruses, including phony websites, to trick job-seekers into helping transfer stolen funds.

encumber.word_example: Two others were making slower progress for the reason that each was  encumbered by supporting a disabled man.

convince.word_definition: make realize the truth or validity of something
convince.word_example: But though he listened he was not  convinced.

bouillon.word_example: The meat soups are called broths,  bouillon, or consommé, according to their richness.

eschew.word_definition: avoid and stay away from deliberately
eschew.word_example: Morrissey is among those seniors who are  eschewing nursing homes in favor of independent living.

atavism.word_definition: a reappearance of an earlier characteristic
atavism.word_example: Criminal  atavism might be defined as the sporadic reversion to savagery in certain individuals.

credo.word_definition: any system of principles or beliefs
credo.word_example: She preferred to hang out with everyone but was best friends with no one, holding to the  credo: “You should be nice to people.”

pilfer.word_definition: make off with belongings of others
pilfer.word_example: Many young people scavenge for reusable garbage, living on proceeds from  pilfered construction material and other recyclables.

skittish.word_example: That combined with his calm and reassuring tone made me think of an animal trainer trying to woo  skittish wild animals.

slew.word_definition: a large number or amount or extent
slew.word_example: In fact, intense focus may be one reason why so-called savants become so extraordinary at performing extensive calculations or remembering a  slew of facts.

madrigal.word_definition: an unaccompanied partsong for several voices
madrigal.word_example: Nevertheless we learn from Malvezzi's publication that the pieces were all written in the  madrigal style, frequently in numerous voice parts.

constant.word_definition: a quantity that does not vary
constant.word_example: In 1929, Hubble independently put forward and confirmed the same idea, and the parameter later became known as the Hubble  constant.

surly.word_definition: unfriendly and inclined toward anger or irritation
surly.word_example: But Blake, being  surly and quarrelsome even when sober, gave the lapel a savage jerk, and reached out with his other hand.

inclusive.word_example: We are going to adhere to our basic programing strategy of nonpartisan information  inclusive of all different points of view.

dearth.word_example: A continuing  dearth of snow in many U.S. spots usually buried by this time of year has turned life upside down.

saturnine.word_example: Only when Bill Lightfoot spoke did he look up, and then with a set sneer, growing daily more  saturnine.

seethe.word_definition: be in an agitated emotional state
seethe.word_example: Outwardly quite calm and matter-of-fact, his mind was in a  seething turmoil.

pedagogue.word_example: His old  pedagogue, Mr. Brownell, had been unable to teach him mathematics.

apropos.word_definition: of an appropriate or pertinent nature
apropos.word_example: I found myself thinking vaguely about things that were not at all  apropos to the situation.

obtuse.word_example: The affair had been mentioned so plainly that it was impossible for the most dense and  obtuse person not to have understood the allusion.

levity.word_example: The same balance of seriousness and  levity runs through her plays, which put an absurdist spin on everyday problems.

gist.word_definition: the central meaning or theme of a speech or literary work
gist.word_example: The syntax was a little off, even comical at times, but I got the  gist of what was going on.

effervescence.word_definition: the property of giving off bubbles
effervescence.word_example: Both were in the very sparkle and  effervescence of that fanciful glee which bubbles up from the golden, untried fountains of early childhood.

redolent.word_example: Here, however, are congregated a vast number of curious and interesting objects, while the place is  redolent of vivid historical associations.

erstwhile.word_example: Sony, whose  erstwhile dominance in consumer electronics has been eroded by the likes of Samsung, could beat rivals to a potentially new generation of devices.

pendulous.word_example: And all around, far out of reach, the trees of the forest were swaying restlessly, their long,  pendulous branches, like tentacles, lashing out hungrily.

retiring.word_example: Foster was an extremely modest, unworldly,  retiring gentleman.

fanfare.word_example: It opened a month ago to considerable  fanfare, with television cameras trailing government officials meandering proudly around the bright new stores filled with imported goods.

concomitant.word_definition: an event or situation that happens at the same time
concomitant.word_example: The conclusion must be drawn that every epidemic of bubonic plague is caused by the  concomitant rat plague.

stake.word_definition: a strong wooden or metal post driven into the ground
stake.word_example: His remains were buried in Cannon Street, and a  stake was driven through the body.

compel.word_example: But the flames grew too large,  compelling firefighters to call off the rescue.

appease.word_definition: cause to be more favorably inclined; gain the good will of
appease.word_example: The king also has tried to  appease public anger over corruption.

bauble.word_definition: cheap showy jewelry or ornament on clothing
bauble.word_example: But men were buying Valentine's  baubles for their honeys long before the first Zales ever opened its doors in a suburban shopping mall.

succor.word_example: Given his health woes, succession worries and persistent isolation, Mr. Kim may simply be seeking  succor from what may be his last friend on earth.

congeal.word_example: Boil down the syrup to half its original quantity, but take care that it does not boil long enough to  congeal or become thick.

whet.word_example: While he described the fishing as “pretty good,” the silver salmon running in the creek only  whetted his appetite to return to Alaska.

sherbet.word_definition: a frozen dessert made primarily of fruit juice and sugar
sherbet.word_example: "One person said it looks like a big lime  sherbet ice cream cone!"

incorrigible.word_example: She scolded and lectured her sister in vain; Cynthia was  incorrigible.

heyday.word_definition: the period of greatest prosperity or productivity
heyday.word_example: Playboy's most popular years are well behind it - the magazine enjoyed its  heyday in the 1970s.

sully.word_example: Why  sully the reputation of an otherwise fascinating online community with really deeply questionable, troubling content?

provender.word_example: "Fools!" she cried, looking in her magic crystal, "he was in the big sycamore under which you stopped to give your horses  provender!"

burnish.word_example: Great cleanliness is enforced in all that belongs to a lighthouse, the reflectors and lenses being constantly  burnished, polished, and cleansed.

nuance.word_definition: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude
nuance.word_example: By working so hard to simplify things, we lose any  nuance or ability to deal with folks’ individual circumstances.

ordain.word_definition: invest with ministerial or priestly authority
ordain.word_example: One of the present bishops was consecrated when quite a young boy, and deacons are often  ordained at sixteen, and even much earlier.

stilted.word_example: But thanks to the  stilted writing and stiff acting, the characters still feel very much like one-dimensional figures from a dutiful fable.

faction.word_example: One  faction declared it would begin an armed struggle against the government of the United States.

entreat.word_example: "Let me go now, please," she  entreated, her eyes unable to meet his any longer.

decadence.word_definition: the state of being degenerate in mental or moral qualities
decadence.word_example: But there are people who really do not want to import what they regard as Western  decadence, especially public drunkenness.

partiality.word_example: She still showed a  partiality for bright colors, by her gown of deep crimson.

polity.word_example: China needs a  polity that can address its increasingly sophisticated society, and to achieve that there must be political reform, Mr. Sun said.

podium.word_definition: a platform raised above the surrounding level
podium.word_example: Leyva beamed as he stood atop the  podium, nodding as the American flag was raised and “The Star-Spangled Banner” played in his honor.

unexceptionable.word_definition: completely acceptable; not open to reproach
unexceptionable.word_example: All cowboys are from necessity good cooks, and the fluffy, golden brown biscuits and fragrant coffee of Red's making were  unexceptionable.

errant.word_definition: straying from the right course or from accepted standards
errant.word_example: As the crowd voiced its displeasure, the referees made sure Wisconsin got the ball, but pass was  errant and rolled out of bounds at midcourt.

pacify.word_definition: ease the anger, agitation, or strong emotion of
pacify.word_example: How they  pacified him I don’t know, but at the end of two hours he had cooled off enough to let us go aboard.

proceeding.word_definition: a sequence of steps by which legal judgments are invoked
proceeding.word_example: Chu attended the special court-martial  proceeding on Monday in Hawaii, Hill said.

repeal.word_example: If Republicans  repeal the law, Ms. Schakowsky said, they would be “taking away benefits that seniors are already getting.”

waffle.word_definition: pause or hold back in uncertainty or unwillingness
waffle.word_example: A few days of  waffling back and forth and I ended up going out to a mediocre bistro with my parents.

restrained.word_example: By contrast, Mr. Pei’s  restrained design took time to claim my attention, particularly since it sat quietly next door to Saarinen’s concrete gull wings.

ramify.word_example: Cometary science has  ramified in unexpected ways during the last hundred years.

outskirts.word_definition: outlying areas, as of a city or town
outskirts.word_example: Ms. Waters talked about how she had spent the day at an organic farm on the  outskirts of Beijing looking at vegetables for the dinner.

diadem.word_definition: an ornamental jeweled headdress signifying sovereignty
diadem.word_example: I dethrone monarchs and the people rejoicing crown me instead, showering  diadems upon my head.

bulwark.word_definition: a protective structure of stone or concrete
bulwark.word_example: The cliffs are of imposing height, nearly three hundred feet: a formidable  bulwark.

dissimulate.word_example: From infancy these people have been schooled to  dissimulate and hide emotion, and ordinarily their faces are as opaque as those of veteran poker players.

unmitigated.word_definition: not diminished or moderated in intensity or severity
unmitigated.word_example: In order to be well directed, sympathy must consider all men, and not the individual alone; only then is it an  unmitigated good.

microcosm.word_example: The building, he said, is "a  microcosm of what Shanghai was all about."

cupidity.word_example: Well educated, but very corrupt at heart, he found in his insatiable  cupidity many ways of gaining money.

notion.word_example: Does that old  notion that defense wins championships still hold up these days?

dispassionate.word_definition: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice
dispassionate.word_example: The commission sitting by, judicial,  dispassionate, presided with cold dignity over the sacrifice, and pronounced it good.

accolade.word_definition: a tangible symbol signifying approval or distinction
accolade.word_example: The Nobel Prize, considered one of the highest  accolades in literature, is given only to living writers.

superannuated.word_example: Civil servants are  superannuated at fifty-five years of age and are sent home on a pension, seldom enjoying life longer than two years afterward.

masticate.word_definition: bite and grind with the teeth
masticate.word_example: Food should be  masticated quietly, and with the lips closed.

clarion.word_example: “He has been the single,  clarion voice for commuter rail in central Florida for 20 years,” said Mayor Ken Bradley of Winter Park.

meander.word_definition: move or cause to move in a sinuous or circular course
meander.word_example: They paused beside one of the low stone walls that  meandered in a meaningless fashion this way and that over the uplands.

mordant.word_example: Even Morgan himself, intrepid as he was, shrank from the awful menace of the  mordant words.

pinion.word_example: The prisoners having dismounted, were placed in a line on the ground facing the guillotine, their arms  pinioned.

The Vocabulary.com Top 1000.list_detailed_description: The top 1,000 vocabulary words have been carefully chosen to represent difficult but common words that appear in everyday academic and business writing. These words are also the most likely to appear on the SAT, ACT, GRE, and ToEFL.

Great Expectations Chapters 1-9.list_brief_description: 25 vocabulary words from Chapters 1-9 of Great Expectations.

perspicuity.word_definition: clarity as a consequence of being easily understandable
perspicuity.word_example: Joe recited this couplet with such manifest pride and careful  perspicuity, that I asked him if he had made it himself.

obstinacy.word_definition: resolute adherence to your own ideas or desires
obstinacy.word_example: Whitewash on the forehead hardens the brain into a state of  obstinacy perhaps.

genteel.word_definition: marked by refinement in taste and manners
genteel.word_example: I wished Joe had been rather more genteelly brought up, and then I should have been so too.

cask.word_definition: a cylindrical container that holds liquids
cask.word_example: On the edge of the river I could faintly make out the only two black things in all the prospect that seemed to be standing upright; one of these was the beacon by which the sailors steered,—like an unhooped  cask upon a pole,—an ugly thing when you were near it; the other, a gibbet, with some chains hanging to it which had once held a pirate.

reproachful.word_definition: expressing reproof especially as a corrective
reproachful.word_example: Joe gave a  reproachful cough, as much as to say, "Well, I told you so."

expectorate.word_definition: clear out the chest and lungs
expectorate.word_example: Instantly afterwards, the company were seized with unspeakable consternation, owing to his springing to his feet, turning round several times in an appalling spasmodic whooping-cough dance, and rushing out at the door; he then became visible through the window, violently plunging and  expectorating, making the most hideous faces, and apparently out of his mind.

disputatious.word_example: I think it will be conceded by my most  disputatious reader, that she could hardly have directed an unfortunate boy to do anything in the wide world more difficult to be done under the circumstances.

ignominiously.word_definition: in a dishonorable manner or to a dishonorable degree
ignominiously.word_example: And I soon found myself getting heavily bumped from behind in the nape of the neck and the small of the back, and having my face  ignominiously shoved against the kitchen wall, because I did not answer those questions at sufficient length.

exonerated.word_definition: freed from any question of guilt
exonerated.word_example: My state of mind regarding the pilfering from which I had been so unexpectedly  exonerated did not impel me to frank disclosure; but I hope it had some dregs of good at the bottom of it.

divulge.word_definition: make known to the public information previously kept secret
divulge.word_example: Under the weight of my wicked secret, I pondered whether the Church would be powerful enough to shield me from the vengeance of the terrible young man, if I  divulged to that establishment.

imp.word_example: Would he believe that I was both  imp and hound in treacherous earnest, and had betrayed him?

rumination.word_example: "There's one thing you may be sure of, Pip," said Joe, after some  rumination, "namely, that lies is lies. Howsever they come, they didn't ought to come, and they come from the father of lies, and work round to the same. Don't you tell no more of 'em, Pip. That ain't the way to get out of being common, old chap. And as to being common, I don't make it out at all clear. You are oncommon in some things. You're oncommon small. Likewise you're a oncommon scholar."

flighty.word_example: "My opinion is, it's a sedan-chair. She's  flighty, you know,—very  flighty,—quite  flighty enough to pass her days in a sedan-chair."

imperiously.word_definition: in a manner showing arrogant superiority
imperiously.word_example: But, Uncle Pumblechook, who was omnipotent in that kitchen, wouldn't hear the word, wouldn't hear of the subject,  imperiously waved it all away with his hand, and asked for hot gin and water.

disdainfully.word_example: "Tried to murder him?" said my convict,  disdainfully.

trenchant.word_definition: having keenness and forcefulness and penetration in thought
trenchant.word_example: My sister had a  trenchant way of cutting our bread and butter for us, that never varied.

reticence.word_example: And the mere sight of the torment, with his fishy eyes and mouth open, his sandy hair inquisitively on end, and his waistcoat heaving with windy arithmetic, made me vicious in my  reticence.

goad.word_definition: stab or urge on as if with a pointed stick
goad.word_example: I might have been an unfortunate little bull in a Spanish arena, I got so smartingly touched up by these moral  goads.

vicariously.word_definition: indirectly, as, by, or through a substitute
vicariously.word_example: My sister, having so much to do, was going to church  vicariously, that is to say, Joe and I were going.

gluttony.word_example: "Swine," pursued Mr. Wopsle, in his deepest voice, and pointing his fork at my blushes, as if he were mentioning my Christian name,—"swine were the companions of the prodigal. The  gluttony of Swine is put before us, as an example to the young."

consternation.word_definition: fear resulting from the awareness of danger
consternation.word_example: The wonder and  consternation with which Joe stopped on the threshold of his bite and stared at me, were too evident to escape my sister's observation.

retort.word_definition: a quick reply to a question or remark
retort.word_example: Every Christmas Day, he  retorted, as he now  retorted, "It's no more than your merits. And now are you all bobbish, and how's Sixpennorth of halfpence?" meaning me.

conciliatory.word_definition: making or willing to make concessions
conciliatory.word_example: Joe, who had ventured into the kitchen after me as the dustpan had retired before us, drew the back of his hand across his nose with a  conciliatory air, when Mrs. Joe darted a look at him, and, when her eyes were withdrawn, secretly crossed his two forefingers, and exhibited them to me, as our token that Mrs. Joe was in a cross temper.

contumacious.word_example: "Trouble?" echoed my sister; "trouble?" and then entered on a fearful catalogue of all the illnesses I had been guilty of, and all the acts of sleeplessness I had committed, and all the high places I had tumbled from, and all the low places I had tumbled into, and all the injuries I had done myself, and all the times she had wished me in my grave, and I had contumaciously refused to go there.

obligated.word_definition: caused by law or conscience to follow a certain course
obligated.word_example: ...without us. So, he'd come with a most tremenjous crowd and make such a row at the doors of the houses where we was, that they used to be  obligated to have no more to do with us and to give us up to him. And then he took us home and hammered us. Which, you see, Pip," said...
